docs.lead_paragraph: Longing to start the 2016 campaign? So's Hillary.
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column analyzes early indications of whether Hillary Clinton will run for president in 2016; questions whether her muted response to Israel's planned new settlements in West Bank was political calculation.
docs.snippet: Longing to start the 2016 campaign? So's Hillary....

docs.lead_paragraph: "Whether you voted for me or you voted for Barack, the time is now to unite as a single party with a single purpose," Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said during her convention speech Tuesday night.
docs.abstract: PUMA's leader has gone home, but the folks from 18 Million Voices are sticking around to hear Barack Obama make his case.

docs.abstract: From the Associated Press: WASHINGTON – Crisp bacon, TiVo and round-the-clock Internet service are just a few of the reasons why Hillary Rodham Clinton loves America. docs.lead_paragraph: One of the best sites for following the presidential campaign is First Read and it wonders aloud after last night's debate whether the Levin Amendment won't come back to haunt Hillary Rodham Clinton. Again last night, Senator Clinton misstated the Levin Amendment and the circumstances preceding the war in Iraq. In reality, Senator Clinton had clearly internalized the way Democrats had gotten into trouble for opposing the first Gulf War and wanted to preserve her political viability. That's why she voted against the Levin Amendment. Here's what First Read says:

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Kathryn Oyer and Nikolaos Linardopoulos, teachers in Philadelphia, were married there yesterday. Archimandrite Nektarios Kotrotsos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. George.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Brooke Cole, a daughter of Mrs. Herbert J. Stiefel and Gordon E. Cole, both of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Richard Fitzgerald McAllister, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John McAllister of New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: SOUTH POLE, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Sir Edmund and a group of Americans led by Rear Admiral George Dufek formed a welcoming committee at the South Pole today for Dr. Fuchs and his British expedition.
